title: 111_s2854
content: Extension and modification of the new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit. Extension and modification of the new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit, amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to extend the deadline to December 31, 2014, and adjusting the qualified incremental hybrid cost limits based on vehicle weight ratings. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the applicable percentage for heavy trucks achieving a 20 percent increase in city fuel economy based on vehicle weight ratings. The new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit deadline is extended to December 31, 2014, with modified limits on qualified incremental hybrid costs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the applicable percentage for heavy trucks achieving a 20 percent increase in city fuel economy based on vehicle weight ratings. The new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit deadline is extended to December 31, 2014, with modified limits on qualified incremental hybrid costs. Additionally, a dollar limitation of $24,000 is set for the credit allowed for vehicles meeting specific fuel economy criteria. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include heavy electric vehicles in the definition of new qualified hybrid motor vehicles. Credits under section 30B may now be transferred. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allow for the transfer of credits for new qualified hybrid motor vehicles, including heavy electric vehicles. The credit can be transferred through an assignment to the seller of the vehicle, with regulations in place to prevent multiple claims. Effective December 31, 2009, the amendments apply to vehicles acquired after that date. SEC. 2. Extension of alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, extending the increased credit for alternative fuel vehicles and redefining alternative fuel vehicle refueling property for electricity-propelled vehicles. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 45R. IDLING REDUCTION CREDIT is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a tax credit for electrification technologies to reduce truck idling. The idling reduction tax credit allows a 50% credit for the purchase and installation of qualifying idling reduction devices or infrastructure, with a maximum credit of $3,500 per device. Qualifying devices are those installed on heavy-duty diesel vehicles designed to reduce idling. The idling reduction tax credit provides a 50% credit for qualifying devices that provide services like heat, air conditioning, or electricity to parked vehicles without using the main engine. The devices can be powered by electricity or dual fuel units, and must be acquired for use by the taxpayer. The idling reduction tax credit offers a 50% credit for qualifying devices that provide services like heat, air conditioning, or electricity to parked vehicles without using the main engine. The devices can be powered by electricity or dual fuel units, must be acquired for use by the taxpayer, and certified by the Secretary of Energy to reduce long-duration idling at motor vehicle rest stops. The term 'heavy-duty diesel-powered on-highway vehicle' includes vehicles used for transportation of passengers or property on highways. The term 'long duration idling' refers to the operation of a main drive engine for more than 15 consecutive minutes without being engaged in gear, excluding routine stoppages due to traffic. 'Qualifying idle reduction infrastructure' is off-truck equipment used exclusively for vehicles with a gross weight rating of 14,000 pounds or more, providing electric power. The section discusses the provision of various connections and services to one truck space, including electric receptacles, boxes, wiring, conduit, air conditioning, heating, and electric power. It also states that no double benefit is allowed, reducing the basis of the property by the amount of the credit determined under this section. The section provides details on the idling reduction tax credit, stating that no double benefit is allowed and reducing the property's basis by the credit amount. Taxpayers can elect not to claim the credit, and the section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2013. Additionally, the credit is included as part of the general business credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item after section 45P. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new idling reduction credit under section 45R. Amendments also apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. The Secretary of Energy will establish certification standards for idling reduction devices to reduce air pollution and fuel consumption. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with the EPA and DOT, will publish standards for certifying idling reduction devices and infrastructure to reduce air pollution and fuel consumption at vehicle rest stops.
